newsitem.title: CHINA: China to curb nightclubs, other "decadent" culture.
newsitem.headline: China to curb nightclubs, other "decadent" culture.

text.p: China's cultural mandarins will curb the building of nightclubs and video parlours in a drive to wipe out decadent culture and ideas, state media said on Wednesday.
"The Ministry of Culture...will improve its management over the cultural market in 1997, trying every strategy it can to eliminate decadent elements in the country," the Xinhua news agency said.
The ministry would curb the building of new nightclubs and night-time video parlours, Xinhua said.
The authorities would set an "appropriate ratio" for the number of imported and domestic programmes available in China, the agency said without elaborating.
"The cultural market can never be a hotbed for decadent ideology and culture," Xinhua quoted Meng Xiaosi, director of the ministry's Cultural Market Bureau, as saying.
The cultural clean-up drive would help China's ideological and ethical undertakings, the China Daily said.
"The cultural sphere...usually helps to spread patriotism as well as other correct ideas among the public," the official newspaper said.
The ministry had also vowed to eliminate piracy of artistic works and "vulgar" performances, Xinhua said, without giving details on how censors would decide on what was vulgar.
"The ministry plans to basically wipe out the country's influx of pornography and protect intellectual property rights by the year 2000," it said.

Market-oriented reforms launched by paramount leader Deng Xiaoping in the late 1970s have led to a proliferation of dance halls, cinemas and karaoke bars in China, once nearly devoid of entertainment under the strict puritan rule of Mao Zedong.
Beijing has been under intense international pressure to crack down on piracy of movies, music and software.
China and the United States went to the brink of a trade war last June over Beijing's failure to rein in such piracy.
